titleStmt.title: Titanium alloying enhancement of mechanical properties of NbTaMoW refractory high-Entropy alloy: First-principles and experiments perspective

analytic.title: Titanium alloying enhancement of mechanical properties of NbTaMoW refractory high-Entropy alloy: First-principles and experiments perspective

biblStruct.note: Received 16 February 2020 Received in revised form 4 October 2020 Accepted 10 October 2020

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: High entropy alloys First-principle calculation Phase structure Elastic properties Electronic structure

div.p: Poor ductility of Refractory high entropy alloys (RHEAs) at room temperature (RT) is the main problem restricting their practical applications. Alloying is an effective method to improve the mechanical properties of RHEAs. Here, Ti was employed to enhance the RT ductility of NbTaMoW RHEAs by means of alloying. The influence of Ti addition on the mechanical properties of the equiatomic NbTaMoW RHEA was investigated from the perspective of first-principles calculation combining experiments. The phase structure, lattice parameters, densities, elastic properties and electronic structure were calculated, respectively. The results show that NbMoTaW and NbMoTaWTi alloy were single-phase BCC structure. Both alloys were electrically conductive and shown metallic characteristic. Ti alloying effectively enhanced the atomic interaction, strength and ductility of NbMoTaW alloy due to the increasing TieTi metallic bonds and decreasing covalent bonds. The calculated data were well agreed with the experimental results, demonstrating that first-principles calculation was an effective method to predict the alloying performance enhancement of RHEAs.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: High entropy alloys (HEAs), with single BCC, FCC or HCP solid solution structure, become a hot researching area for their excellent properties compared with the traditionally alloys [1e5]. HEAs usually contain 5 to 13 primary elements and are classified as transition high entropy alloy (THEAs) and refractory high entropy alloys (RHEAs). THEAs are made from transition elements containing Fe, Co, Ni, Cr, Mn, Cu, and Al. Such as, CrMnFeCoNi [6e8], AlCoCrCuFeNi [9], AlCrFeCoNi [10,11], CoCrFeNi 2.1 Nb x [12] and so on. RHEAs are composed of refractory elements with high melting points. Compared with THEAs, RHEAs have outstanding high temperature resistance, high melting points (>2000 C) and high strength at elevated temperatures. They are the promising high temperature structure materials in aerospace, aviation, and metallurgy. Among the RHEAs, NbMoTaW [13,14] alloy is the typical representative due to its high melting temperature and superior properties. Since firstly reported by Senkov et al., in 2010, this alloy attracts much attention. The most attractive feature of Mo 25 Nb 25 Ta 25 W 25 alloy is its high temperature resistance. The compressive strength reaches 405 MPa at 1600 C and it is still stable and possesses a single BCC structure at 1400 C. The surprised performances make it to be considered as a new superalloy which breaks through the temperature limits (1200 C) of existing superalloys like nickel-based alloys [15e18]. However, the fracture strain of Mo 25 Nb 25 Ta 25 W 25 RHEA at room temperature is only 2.6% [13], exhibiting a brittle fracture behavior. Poor ductility at room temperature limits its further development and engineering application. How to improve the room temperature ductility of Mo 25 Nb 25 Ta 25 W 25 RHEAs is an important measure to optimize the alloy's properties and promote its application. Commonly, some measures such as adjusting the process and composition of RHEAs were used to improve its low room temperature ductility and promote its bright application prospects. Alloying is also one of the general and practical measures to improve the ductility of RHEAs and traditional alloys. To change the status of poor ductile alloys, Ishida et al. [19] added alloying element (Fe, Co, and Cr) to improve ductility of NiAl(B2)-based alloys. Sandl€ obes et al. [20] improved the ductility of Mg alloys by alloying elements with relatively high (>1 at.%) solid solubility. Kazuya et al. [21] enhanced the ductility of CoeAleW high-temperature alloys by adding boron element. Especially, Han et el [22,23] added Ti to strength NbMoTaW RHEA and their idea was confirmed by the experiments. They thought that the improvement of the mechanical properties tested by the compression experiment was attributed to the relatively high solid solution hardening (SSH) effect. However, the strengthening effect was only interpreted from experimental perspective, which lacks further discussion and explanation of the mechanism from atom and electron interaction. To the authors' knowledge, most researchers make achievements of ductility enhancement by means of alloying using experimental investigation. The analysis of ductility enhancement from the view point of atom or electron is rarely reported. Zhang el al [24,25] explored the long-ranged interaction and configurational energy of NbMoTaWTi RHEA from effective pair interaction (EPI) perspective, which laid a solid foundation for theoretical calculation of NbMoTaWTi RHEA. Nevertheless, the micro-mechanism of alloying performance improvement was not discussed and need further investigation. In present work, Ti was chosen as the alloying element to enhance the room temperature ductility of NbMoTaW RHEA. The influence of Ti alloying on the mechanical properties of the equiatomic NbMoTaW RHEA was investigated from the perspective of first-principles calculation combining experiments. First-principles calculation based on density functional theory (DFT) [26,27] was employed to predict the phase structure, lattice constants, densities, elastic properties and electrical properties of NbMoTaW and NbMoTaWTi RHEAs. Particularly, the energy band, the total and partial densities of states and charge density were calculated to investigate the mechanism of strength and ductility enhancement of NbMoTaW alloy by means of Ti alloying.

div.head: Theoretical methods and calculation models
div.p: In this work, all the calculations were performed using CASTEP module [28,29]. The special quasi-random supercell method (SQS) [30] was adopted to build the crystal models, which was expanded based on Nb bulk with single-phase BCC structure. In the following parts, the equiatomic NbMoTaW and the Ti alloyed NbMoTaWTi RHEA were named as Ti0 and Ti1 alloy, respectively. Fig. 1 shows 1 Â 1 Â 2 and 1 Â 1 Â 5 supercell models of Ti0 and Ti1 alloys, respectively. During calculations, norm conserving pseudopotential [31] was employed to describe the electron and ionic interaction. The electronic exchange-correlation terms were described using Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) [32] and Perdew Burke Ernzerhof (PBE) function [33,34]. After convergence testing, the cut energy of plane wave and k-point were set as 450eV and 8 Â 8 Â 4 for Ti0 alloy, and 700eV and 8 Â 8 Â 2 for Ti1 alloy, respectively. The valence electrons of all the elements are Nb 4d 4 5s 1 , Mo 4d 5 s 1 , Ta 5d 3 6s 2 , W 5d 4 6s 2 , and Ti 3d 2 4s 2 . The tolerances of the selfconsistent field (SCF), energy, maximum forces and maximum displacement were 1 Â 10 À6 eV/atom, 1 Â 10 À5 eV/atom, 0.03 eV/Å and 0.001 Å, respectively.

div.head: Experimental
div.p: In order to confirm the theoretical results, Ti0 and Ti1 alloys were prepared by non-consumable vacuum arc melting method, respectively. All the elements with a purity of 99.9 wt% were cleaned and polished, and then mixed with equal atomic ratio. The order of placing components was carried out to be NbeMoeTaeW and NbeMoeTieTaeW relying on the melting point, phase diagram and so on. After several rejecting and discharging the high purity of argon, the mixed alloy materials were melted at least five times to ensure the uniformity of components and tissues. X-ray diffraction (XRD, Cu Ka radiation, Rigaku D/Max 2550VB-) was employed to identify the phase structure of both RHRAs. The scanning rate and angle were set as 5 /min and 20 o -90 . Microhardness of the alloys was measured by Vickers hardness tester. The value of hardness was determined by taking an average value among three different points under 100 g for 15s. The heat-treated experiment was carried out in a tubular resistance heating furnace. Ti1 alloy was heated to 1000 C for 10 h under the protecting surroundings of argon. Engineering compression stress-strain curves were obtained using universal testing machine. All samples with the cylindrical size of Ф5 Â 8 mm were cut using wire electricaldischarge machining. All surface of the compressive testing samples was lightly polished to reduce the friction coefficient between the samples and testing machine. The loading rate during compression tests was 0.5 mm/min.

div.head: Phase structure, lattice constants and density
div.p: Table 1 is the formation enthalpy (E form ), cohesive energy (E coh ) and the total energy (E tot ) of the Ti1 alloy. E form and E coh were used to identify the phase structure of alloys and were calculated by the formula ( 1) and ( 2).
div.formula: H form ¼ 1 N x E tot À X n x E x solid(1)
E coh ¼ 1 N x E tot À X n x E x atom(2)
div.p: Here, E tot is the total energy of optimized Ti1 alloy. N x and n x represent the atomic numbers of all and every component. E x solid is the total energy of average atom in a single crystal cell for every component in Ti1 alloy. E x atom is the total energy of isolated atom in a crystal cell.

The calculated data show that both E form and E coh of BCC Ti1 alloy are negative. Among three structures, Ti1 alloy of BCC structure with the lower E form and E coh will first form and be stable [35]. This demonstrates Ti1 alloy is still a single-phase BCC solid solution.

Fig. 2 is the theoretical and experimental XRD patterns of Ti0 and Ti1 alloys. The theoretical XRD patterns of these alloys were calculated by Powder Diffraction (Reflex module, Materials Studio). The experimental XRD patterns of Ti0 and Ti1 alloys containing the as-cast state and the heat-treated state samples were measured and also plotted in Fig. 2. As seen, all the alloys display a singlephase BCC structure. The XRD pattern shows the same phase (BCC) with the results calculated by energy. Both Ti-added alloy and Ti-free alloy are the same structure, i.e. BCC structure. Additionally, the heat treated Ti1 alloy was also identified to be a single-phase BCC structure, indicating that it could sustain the phase structure after annealing at 1000 C for 10 h. Fortunately, our theoretical and experimental XRD patterns are well consistent with the experimental results measured by Han and Senkov [13,22].

Commonly, the lattice constant is an important structural parameter of RHEAs. In this work, the lattice constants of Ti0 and Ti1 RHEA were also calculated. As seen in Table 2, the calculated lattice constants of Ti0 and Ti1 alloy increase from 3.204 to 3.223 Å.

Additionally, Han et al. [23] found that the lattice constants increase from 3.226 Å of Ti0 alloy to 3.240 Å for Ti1 alloy by analyzing the experimental XRD patterns. Ti atom possesses the largest atomic radio among the mentioned five atoms. The larger atomic size difference results in the severe lattice distortion. Therefore, the lattice constant increases after Ti addition. This also well agrees with the calculated data. Besides, the increasing lattice constant also causes the decrease of the alloy's density. The empirical densities of Ti0 and Ti1 alloys were estimated to be 13.668 g/cm 3 and 11.836 g/cm 3 by the rule of mixtures (ROM) [36] using formula (3).
div.formula: r mix ¼ X n i¼1 c i ðrÞ i(3)
div.p: Here,r mix refers to empirical density for the alloys. c i and ðrÞ i are the content and density for the ith components. The calculated densities of Ti0 and Ti1 alloys were 14.023 g/cm 3 and 12.821 g/cm 3 . The experimental densities measured by the Archimedes method were 13.63 g/cm 3 to 11.98 g/cm 3 . Generally, the above theoretical data are well consistent with others experiments [14], demonstrating that the calculated parameters and selective models are feasible.

div.head: Elastic properties
div.p: Table 3 displays the elastic constants of Ti0 and Ti1 RHEAs by calculating supercell models. The calculated results usually contain nine independent elastic constants due to low symmetry and lager size of supercell models [36,37]. Therefore, we deal with the data by formula (4) and the average elastic constants are shown in Table 4.

As seen, the values of C 11 ¼ 392 GPa, C 12 ¼ 158 GPa, and C 44 ¼ 79 GPa of Ti0 alloy are well agreed with the data of C 11 ¼ 400 GPa, C 12 ¼ 178 GPa, and C 44 ¼ 75 GPa of NbTaMoW calculated by Li [38]. It can be seen that elastic constants (C 11 , C 12 , C 44 ) decrease after Ti addition. Elastic constants are directly relative to bulk modulus (B), shear modulus (G) and Yong's modulus (E). Commonly, the large elastic constants are corresponding to the high elastic modulus. The polycrystalline elastic modulus of Ti0 and Ti1 alloys were acquired by Viogt-Reuss-Hill (VRH) method [39]. The larger the bulk modulus is, the stronger the incompressibility of materials is. Additionally, the greater the shear modulus is, the stronger the shear deformation resistance of material is. The values of B, G and E decrease as the same variation of C 11 , C 12 and C 44 . Thus, the compressive strength is considered to be improved after Ti addition. The value of B, G and E are 236 GPa, 92 GPa and 245 GPa of Ti0 alloy and 200 GPa, 73 GPa and 196 GPa of Ti1 alloy. This is in good agreement with 139 GPa, 59 GPa and 156 GPa of Ti1 measured by Han [22]. In other words, it occurred that the strength of NbMoTaW RHEA will be enhanced after Ti addition.

Normally, the Pugh ratio (G/B), Poisson's ratio (y) and Cauchy pressure (C 12 eC 44 ) are the most common criterion to predict the brittleness or ductility of the hard materials. G/B ¼ 0.57, as a boundary value, is usually used to judge the behavior of brittleness/ ductility. Smaller than the value, the materials show ductility. The smaller the G/B is, the better the ductility is. Larger than the value, it exhibits brittle behavior. According to calculated data, all the G/B values are smaller than 0.57 and they decrease from 0.390 of Ti0 alloy to 0.365 of Ti1 alloy. Therefore, it is thought that Ti addition effectively improves the ductility of NbMoTaW RHEA. The ductility enhancement may arise from the severe lattice distortion and solution strengthening [40] after adding Ti with lager radius.

For the positive Cauchy pressure (C 12 eC 44 ), it is identified as the predictive condition of forming metallic bond. The values of C 12 eC 44 were calculated to be positive, indicating that both Ti0 and Ti1 alloys were metallic bonding. On the other hand, Poisson's ratio (y) is also an important criterion to decide the brittleness/ductility of alloys. If y > 0.33, the alloys exhibit ductile behavior. Otherwise, alloys display brittle fracture. The values of y increase from 0.327 of Ti0 alloy to 0.337 of Ti1 alloy. The data of y shows that Ti0 alloy (y ¼ 0.327 < 0.33) is brittle fracture, which is similar to the intergranular fracture mode reported in Refs. [13,23]. In addition, all the alloys are mechanically stable because the elastic constants satisfy Born Rule (C 11 > 0; C 44 > 0;

Hardness is a kind of ability of the materials to resist the local deformation, which is closely related to ductility of alloys. Thus, hardness of Ti0 and Ti1 alloy were calculated according to formula (5) and shown in Fig. 3.

As seen in Fig. 3, the hardness has a little fluctuate between Ti0 and Ti1 alloys. The calculated value (457HV) of Ti1 alloy is well consistent with the experimental value (498HV) [22]. The predicted hardness (636HV) of Ti0 alloy is higher than the experimental value (446HV) [14]. The predicted and experimental hardness of Ti1 alloy are highly anastomosis.

div.head: Electronic structure
div.p: The calculated results about electric structure can character material's electric and mechanical properties from the respective of atomic and electric scale. Energy bond, one of the basic electric structure, generates from the energy level of isolated atoms. That is to say, the more compact energy bond represents the stronger atomic ever eletrical interaction. The materials with stronger atomic interaction exhibit better mechanical properties and ductility. Therefore, the energy bond structure of Ti0 and Ti1 alloys were calculated to inverstigate the influence of Ti addition on the mechanical performance enhancement of NbMoTaW-based RHEA. Fig. 4(aec) is the energy bond structure plots of Ti0 and Ti1 alloy. Fig. 4 (b) is the drawing of partial enlargement. The red dotted line in the picture is the Fermi energy level. As seen in Fig. 4, serious hybridization of energy bond between valence bond and conduction bond indicates that Ti0 and Ti1 alloy exhibit metallic characteristic [42]. Futhermore, the energy bond becomes more compact after Ti addition, demonstrating that atomic interaction of Ti1 alloy is stronger than one of Ti0 alloy. Ti alloying is contributable to the mechanical performance enhancement of NbMoTaW RHEA. Interestingly, Fig. 4 (c) appears extra energy bonds at lower energy region after Ti addition, which is attributed to the contribution of Ti and the formation of TieTi metalic bond.

In order to further investigate the electric contribution and bonding characteristic of Ti0 and Ti1 alloy. The total and partial As can be seen from Fig. 5, Ti0 and Ti1 alloy are electrically conductive and show metallic properties due to the high densities of state at Fermi energy level [43,44]. Seen from Fig. 5 (a), the density of state distributes from À10eV to 30eV, which is mainly coming from the contribution of d-orbital and p-orbital electrons.

Existing severe electrical hybridization among Nb, Mo, Ta and W leads to the forming of covalent bond [45]. In Fig. 5 (c), after Ti addition, there are two alone, thin and small peaks at the lower energy region. The two peaks are completely resulted from Ti contribution without participating of Nb, Mo, Ta and W. Therefore, it is thought that the TieTi metallic bond was formed in Ti1 alloy system. In Fig. 5, it is not difficult to find that the conduction bond moves to Fermi energy level, indicating that the covalence of Ti0 alloy system was weakened after Ti addition. Interestingly, it is found that the density of state of Ti contribution is higher than that of Nb, Mo, Ta and W. In other words, more TieTi metallic bond will be formed after Ti addition, which may lead to the strength and ductility enhancement of Ti0 alloy.

In order to further study the bond characteristic of Ti0 and Ti1 alloys, the charge densities were calculated and plotted in Fig. 6. Fig. 6 (a) displays stronger electric cloud overlapping among Nb, Mo Ta and W atoms, indicating the formation of the covalent bonds [46]. Seen from Fig. 6 (b), the charge around Ti atom is circular distributed and there is a little overlapping with the other four atoms. Therefore, it is thought that the TieTi metallic bond was formed in Ti1 alloy system. The formation of the TieTi metallic bond is the same as the previous analysis of the total and partial densities of states. The increasing TieTi metallic bonds and the decreasing covalent bonds in NbMoTaW-based RHEA demonstrate that Ti alloying helps to improve the ductility of NbMoTaW RHEAs.

div.head: Mechanical properties
div.p: In the previous investigation based on DFT calculation, Ti alloying obviously helps to improve the strength and ductility of NbMoTaW RHEA. In order to confirm this result, Ti alloyed NbMoTaWTi RHEA were prepared and its mechanical properties at the as-casted and annealed states were respectively tested. Fig. 7 shows the engineering compression stress-strain curves of Ti alloyed RHEA at the as-casted and annealed states. The illustration in Fig. 7 shows the engineering compression stress-strain curve of Ti-free NbMoTaW RHEA measured by Senkov [13]. Seen from Fig. 7, the compressive strength of Ti alloyed NbMoTaWTi RHEA reaches about 1600 MPa, which is approximately 1.5 times larger than that of NbMoTaW alloy (1200 MPa). The fracture strain is also much larger than that of NbMoTaW alloy (2.6%). The compressive stressstrain curve of Ti alloyed RHEA is well consistent with the experimental results measured by Han [22,23]. The compressive strength of the annealed Ti alloyed RHEA decreases a little compared with that of the as-casted alloy. However, the fracture strain is still larger than that of NbMoTaW alloy. Totally, the strength and ductility of Ti alloyed NbMoTaWTi RHEA were obviously improved compared with Ti-free NbMoTaW RHEA according to the above experiments. This is in good agreement with the previous results based on DFT calculation. Both theoretical calculation and experiments indicate that Ti alloying is beneficial to improve the mechanical properties of NbMoTaW RHEA.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Ti alloying was designed to improve the mechanical performance of NbMoTaW RHEA and the strengthening effect was investigated based on first-principle calculation combining experiments. The phase structure, lattice parameters, densities, elastic properties and electronic structure of NbMoTaW alloy and Ti alloyed NbMoTaWTi RHEA were predicted using first-principle calculation. The calculated and experimental results show that Tifree and Ti alloyed RHEAs have BCC single-phase solid solution structure. Both Ti alloyed and Ti-free RHEAs were predicted to be electrically conductive and shown metallic characteristic. Ti alloyed RHEA exhibited better strength and ductility compared with Ti-free RHEA according to the stronger atomic interaction and the formation of TieTi metallic bonds, which was observed and explained in the energy bonds structure, total and partial densities of states and charge density diagram. The improved performance due to Ti alloying were further characterized by the proposed empirical formulas such as C 12 eC 44 , y, G/B and HV. In order to confirm Ti alloying enhancement of the mechanical performance, Ti alloyed NbMoTaWTi RHEA were prepared and its mechanical properties were tested. Ti alloyed RHEA exhibits much larger strength and ductility compared with that of Ti-free alloy, which well agrees with the results based on calculations. Both theoretical calculation and experiments indicate that Ti alloying is beneficial to improve the mechanical properties of NbMoTaW RHEA. This work indicates that first-principle calculation is an effective method to predict the properties of RHEAs. In the further investigation, the larger supercell and long-ranged interaction should be considered during the calculation in order to refine the prediction.

div.head: CRediT authorship contribution statement
div.p: Linhui Bai: contributed the central idea, analyzed most of the data, and wrote the initial draft of the paper, The remaining authors contributed to refining the ideas, carrying out additional analyses and finalizing this paper. Yonggang Tong: contributed the central idea, analyzed most of the data, and wrote the initial draft of the paper, The remaining authors contributed to refining the ideas, carrying out additional analyses and finalizing this paper.
